article_title: Website would match jobs with workers on hours' notice
article_text:
Website would match jobs with workers on hours' notice

Say you work in fast food, and the four-hour shift you were counting on later today just got canceled because business is slow. Or maybe you own the franchise and the employee you were depending upon to handle an upcoming rush just called in sick.

article_metadata.description: [...] Snagajob, a website that specializes in hourly wage work, is developing a way for job seekers to plug last-minute holes in their schedules at the same time it rolls out a way for employers to fill their empty shifts.  Borrowing technology concepts from startups that have thrown long-standing taxi operations and hoteliers a curve ball, Snagajob is launching a new product that combines a rating system with just-in-time staffing.  According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, 77.2 million workers nationwide toil for an hourly wage - 58.7 percent of all U.S. workers.  Christin Fernandez, director of media relations and public affairs for the National Restaurant Association, said in an email that flexibility is central to the restaurant industry.  Hamilton said pieces of the Snagajob system are already in place, including video interviewing, personality assessments and systems for managing paperwork such as tax forms and direct deposit authorizations.The scheduling piece is set to roll out mid-2016.  Hamilton is confident Snagajob and its thousands of pre-existing relationships with companies and job seekers can work through any hiccups to get the online match-up system up and running.
article_metadata.author.name: By L.M. Sixel
